So we'll be talking about something really classic to networking that spanning tree protocol. I'll talk about what it is and also cover three important points regarding spanning tree.

Guys, this is so important throughout your whole career. This will be tested over and over and over again. So Jacob, thanks for bringing this to our listeners. Go ahead and let's get started. Okay. So spanning tree protocol, it's IEEE 802.1D. Then we also have a rapid spanning tree protocol, which is 802.1W. So spanning tree protocol, we'll just say this. I'm not going to refer to the IEEE standards anymore, but I just wanted to mention what they are. So spanning tree protocol is used for switched network loop avoidance. So whenever you have two switches and you place one connection between them, there is no loop between those switches. There can't be. There's only one connection. But as soon as you add a second cable or redundant connection between those switches, well now you have two connections between those switches and there's a possible loop.

But without spanning tree protocol, what would happen if you had these two connections is that the frames would continuously get repeated between those two connections, which would continuously build and build and build the traffic, which would eventually crash the switches. So without spanning tree switches would crash every time that a new redundant connection was added. So spanning tree protocol is for preventing loops in your network in your switch network. So spanning tree works by default on Cisco switches and also most other switches. And there's some kind of essential things that we need to understand about what spanning tree does on the actual switch port whenever you connect a cable between the two switches.

So the first thing that it's going to do is it's going to block the port. Then it's going to listen for BPDUs or listen for spanning tree packets. Then it's going to learn about the spanning tree topology and then start forwarding. So this is with traditional spanning tree. It's blocking, listening, learning and then forwarding. Finally, where it starts sending frames. And then we have something called rapid spanning tree, which is newer. And the reason why I'm mentioning both of these is because you'll see them in the text and rapid spanning tree, the port states are discarding and then learning and forwarding. And it basically makes things happen a lot faster.

And it basically makes things happen a lot faster. So then we also have some spanning tree port roles. So the port roles are important because whenever you look at the spanning tree topology on the switch by doing like a show spanning tree command, for example, you're going to see the ports listed as either designated non designated or a root port. And then a designated port that means it's a port that's in the forwarding state. If it's a non designated port, it's actually blocking or discarding. And then a root port is a port that's in a porting state that leads back to the root bridge. So those are really the basic things that you need to understand about how spanning tree goes through these different port states and what those port roles are.

So the second main point I wanted to mention is that switches talk to each other about spanning tree by sending something called BPD use, which is a bridge protocol data unit. So the bridge protocol data unit includes the MAC address of the switch and some spanning tree information. So this is important because not only do the switches use this to talk about spanning tree, but it also helps with the election of what is called the root bridge. And it's really important to understand in spanning tree what the root bridge actually is. The spanning tree topology will send traffic toward the root bridge. So if the root bridge is at the edge of your network, you're going to have traffic passing in a way that is very inefficient and is not the most effective use of your switch network. You don't want traffic passing out to the edge of your network to go back to the core.

So it's important to make sure that the root bridge is actually placed at the core of the network. In order to make sure that this happens, we need to manually configure the root bridge to be at the core of the network. Many networks, they have a self-elected root bridge, meaning that people just go install the switches and then they let the switches just converge the spanning tree and elect the root bridge by default based on the MAC address. Manual root bridge configuration is something that people a lot of times don't do, but good engineers should always make sure that they do do this. So to be a good engineer regarding spanning tree, always make sure that you're manually configuring the spanning tree root bridge to be at the core of the network. Now you also need to keep in mind that there's something out there called PVST, which is per-vLAN spanning tree.

And that basically means that there is a separate root bridge on a per-vLAN basis. Now this is important because you can actually use PVST to balance your VLAN traffic between two core switches, where you have one core switch acting as the root bridge for half of the VLANs on your network, and the other core switch acting as a root bridge for the other half of the VLANs on your network. So with this configuration, this actually makes traffic across the spanning tree be more balanced, and you get better utilization out of your network by setting it up this way, and you're getting better usage of all the ports on all your switches, and the actual flow of traffic across the spanning tree is utilizing more of the network than if you just had a single root bridge. And this is possible whenever you have a dual core kind of setup.

And this is possible whenever you have a dual core kind of setup. Alright, well thanks Jacob for giving us the tech lesson of the day.
